revision.text:
{{Infobox person |name = Scott Stanley Haraburda |image = Colonel Scott S. Haraburda, Commander, 464th Chemical Brigade.jpg |image_size = |alt = |caption = ''464th Chem. Bde command photo, April 2006'' |birth_date = {{birth year and age|1963}}{{cite web |url= http://cocatalog.loc.gov/cgi-bin/Pwebrecon.cgi?Search_Arg=haraburda%2C+scott&Search_Code=NALL&PID |title= Copyright Public Catalog (for Scott S. Haraburda) |publisher= US Copyright Office |accessdate= 19 September 2015}} |birth_place = |home_town= [[Grand Rapids, Michigan]]{{cite book |last= Haraburda |first= Scott S. |title= Christian Controversies: Seeking the Truth |publisher= Meaningful Publications |date= 2013 |isbn= 978-0-9886072-0-0 }} |residence= [[Spencer, Indiana]] |spouse = {{marriage| Marie A.''(née Stressman)''|2010}}{{cite web |author=staff |url= http://www.spencereveningworld.com/news/2011-02-28/Front_Page/Colonel_Haraburda_Inducted_Into_Universitys_ROTC_H.html | title= Colonel Haraburda Inducted Into University's ROTC Hall Of Fame: Spencer's Colonel Scott Haraburda Inducted For Distinguished Service | newspaper= Spencer Evening World | date=28 February 2011| volume=84 | issue=169 | pages=1 |accessdate= 7 July 2015}}{{cite web |title= Indiana State Library Genealogy Database: Marriages: 1958-2012 | url= https://www.statelib.lib.in.us/INMarriages93to02/IN_marriages_display.asp?ID=2617145 | publisher= [[Indiana State Library]] | accessdate = 19 September 2015}} |children= Ashlee, Beverly, Krystal, Jessica, Christine{{sfn|Haraburda|2013|p=iv}} |parents= |module = {{Infobox scientist |embed = yes |alma_mater = [[Grand Rapids Community College|Grand Rapids Jr. Col.]]([[Associate degree|AA]])
[[Central Michigan University|Central Michigan Univ]] ([[Bachelor of Science|BS]])
[[Michigan State University|Mich State Univ]] ([[Master of Science|MS]], [[Doctor of Philosophy|PhD]]) |thesis_title = Transport phenomena of flow through helium and nitrogen plasmas in microwave electrothermal thrusters |thesis_url = http://search.proquest.com/docview/304703595 |thesis_year = 2001 |doctoral_advisor = Martin C. Hawley |awards = Fellow, [[National Society of Professional Engineers|NSPE]]
Hall of Fame, CMU ROTC |module ={{Infobox military person |embed = yes |allegiance = {{flagu|United States of America}} |branch = {{army|USA}}
[[File:Chemical Branch Insignia.svg|23px]] [[Chemical Corps]] |serviceyears = 1981-2010 |rank = [[Image:US-O6 insignia.svg|24px]] [[Colonel (United States)|Colonel]] |commands = [[File:472dChemBnDUI.jpg|23px]] 472d Chem Bn
[[File:464ChemBdeSSI.svg|23px]] [[464th Chemical Brigade (United States)|464th Chem Bde]] |battles = [[Image:Global War on Terrorism Expeditionary ribbon.svg|30px]] [[Global War on Terrorism|GWOT - Kuwait]] |awards = [[Image:Legion of Merit ribbon.svg|30px]] [[Legion of Merit]]
[[Image:Meritorious Service ribbon.svg|30px]] [[Meritorious Service Medal (United States)|Meritorious Svc Med]] }} }} }} '''Scott Stanley Haraburda''' is an American soldier, engineer and inventor. In addition to making key contributions to the development of [[heat exchangers]] and [[spacecraft propulsion]], he led a team of military officers in 2007 to [[Kuwait]] to correct many of the contingency contracting problems identified by the [[Gansler Commission]]. He is known nationally as the president of the Indiana Society of Professional Engineers who led the opposition to a state governmental panel recommendation in 2015 to eliminate licensing of engineers in [[Indiana]]. ==Career== ===Military=== [[File:Army Science Board Meeting February 2005.jpg|thumb|left|Army Secretary [[Francis J. Harvey|Harvey]] (center) presents an award to Dr. Tegnelia (left) as LTC Haraburda (right) reads the citation in 2005. (ASB Photo Archives.)]] Colonel Scott S. Haraburda spent nearly three decades serving in the [[US Army]], providing significant contributions to [[military logistics]], [[CBRN defense|CBRNE defense]], and [[military science]]. In 1991 while he was teaching chemistry at the [[United States Military Academy]], the Army Astronaut Nomination Selection Board nominated Haraburda as a [[NASA Astronaut Corps#Members|NASA astronaut candidate]].{{cite letter |first= Glen D. |last= Skirvin |recipient= Captain Scott S. Haraburda |subject= Army Astronaut Nomination Selection |url= https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Army_Astronaut_Candidate_Nomination_Haraburda.pdf |date= 29 May 1991 |publisher= Department of the Army }} A few years later by means of a competitive selection at the rank of Major, he served as a representative of the [[United States]] to [[Germany]] in 1995 through the ''Army Reserve’s Foreign Exchange Program'' with the [[Bundeswehr]], Germany’s army.{{cite journal | author = Burbach, Mike | title = In step with an ally: Reservist eats, sleeps and trains with German army as part of exchange program | journal = [http://www.usar.army.mil/resources/Pages/WarriorCitizen.aspx Army Reserve Magazine] | volume = 41 | issue = 1 | pages = 20–21 | date = 1996 | quote= A combat support battalion at the [[Zweibrücken|Niederauerbach]] Kaserne (barracks) near the French border in southwestern Germany hosted Haraburda and four other Reservists. The U.S. Army Reserve Command sponsors the exchange program. Germany and the [[United Kingdom]] are participating nations. ... Haraburda visited historical sites, including an abandoned bunker complex on the former [[Maginot Line]]. And various military installations and museums. At a maintenance facility, Haraburda sat in a submerged personnel carrier for 15 minutes during a leak test (a snorkel delivered fresh air).}} In 2005, he served as the Executive Secretary of the [[Army Science Board]], helping its distinguished members of corporate [[Business executive|executive managers]], senior [[academia]]ns, and retired military [[flag officer]]s formulate recommendations to scientific and technological matters of concern to the Army.{{Citation |url= http://asc.army.mil/docs/pubs/alt/2006/1_JanFebMar/articles/70_Army_Science_Board_200601.pdf | author=Haraburda, Scott S. |publication-date=2006 |year=2006 |title=Army Science Board — Providing More Than 50 Years of Scientific Advice and Guidance |volume=PB 70-06-01 |issue=January - February - March | periodical= Army AL&T Magazine | pages=70–73 | accessdate= 3 August 2015}} ====Military Logistics==== In late 2007, Colonel Haraburda deployed to [[Kuwait]] for a year to help correct the contingency contracting problems plaguing the [[Theater (warfare)|war zone]]. The Army deployed him to [[Camp Arifjan]] to lead a small military team of logistics officers in applying the [[LOGCAP]] methods as part of the [[Gansler Commission|Gansler Report's]] second recommendation solution.{{refn|group=lower-alpha|In early 2007, several problems involving contingency contracting surfaced, such as the problems that surrounded the high-visibility [[Cockerham bribery case]], along with the suicides of senior-level contracting and logistics professionals. In August, [[United States Secretary of the Army]], [[Pete Geren]], established an independent commission to review recent operations and provide recommendations.{{cite web|author= Army News Service |url= http://www.army.mil/article/4658/Army_Fights_Contracting_Fraud/ |title= Army Fights Contracting Fraud |publisher=Department of the Army |date=30 August 2007 | quote=The Army went from supporting one Kuwait base camp in 2002 to supporting eight in 2007. Contracts increased from $150 million in 2002 to nearly $1 billion in 2006, and are forecast to reach $1 billion in 2007, according to the secretary. While 20 military and civilian Army employees have been indicted on charges of contract fraud, Sec. Geren said the vast majority of Army contracting professionals fulfill operational requirements everyday for Soldiers serving in harm's way. |accessdate=26 July 2015}} This commission released what became known as the [[Gansler Commission|Gansler Report]] in October 2007.{{cite web|author= Commission on Army Acquisition and Program Management in Expeditionary Operations |url= https://acc.dau.mil/adl/en-US/180366/file/31657/Gansler%20Commission_Report_Final_Report_10-31-07.pdf |title= Urgent Reform Required: Army Expeditionary Contracting |publisher=Department of the Army |date=31 October 2007 | quote= [on page 5, the second key improvement needed was to] Restructure organization and restore responsibility to facilitate contracting and contract management in expeditionary and CONUS operations. |accessdate=26 July 2015}} The second of the four key improvements involved the organizational restructure and change of responsibilities for contingency contracting.{{cite journal | author = Haraburda, Scott S. | author2 = Bloom, Frances A. | author3 = Keck, Robert T. | title = Contracting Agility in LOGCAP-Kuwait | journal = Army Logistician | volume = 41 | issue = 4 | pages = 3–8 | date = 2009 | url = http://www.alu.army.mil/alog/issues/JulAug09/pdf/alog_julaug09.pdf | quote= When Secretary Geren visited the Kuwait contracting office in September 2007, he was so impressed with the requirements generation process of the LOGCAP-Kuwait office that he directed that it be used for all requirements within Kuwait. In essence, the LOGCAP process was identified and directed as a management control in the contracting process. ... Colonel Scott S. Haraburda is the lead logistics support officer in the LOGCAP-Kuwait office.| accessdate =26 July 2015 }}{{cite web |author=staff |url= http://www.spencereveningworld.com/news/2010-10-19/Front_Page/Colonel_Haraburda_Retires_After_Nearly_Three_Decad.html | title= Colonel Haraburda Retires After Nearly Three Decades Of Service; Receives Legion Of Merit | newspaper= Spencer Evening World | date=19 October 2010 | volume=84 | issue=78 | pages=1, 4 | quote= [Colonel Haraburda] began his military career as an enlisted soldier in March of 1981. ... From 2002 through 2004, Colonel Haraburda served as the Battalion Commander of the 472nd Chemical Battalion for over 800 soldiers throughout Indiana and Illinois. ... From 2005 through 2006, Colonel Haraburda was mobilized to the Pentagon to serve as the Executive Secretary of the Army Science Board. ... From 2006 through 2007, Colonel Haraburda served as the Brigade Commander of the 464th Chemical Brigade for over 2,000 soldiers throughout five states of Pennsylvania, Maryland, Virginia, West Virginia and Delaware. ... From 2007 through 2009, Colonel Haraburda deployed to Kuwait to serve as the Senior Logistics Support Officer for the LOGCAP program.|accessdate=26 July 2015}}}} ====CBRNE Defense==== As the commander of the 472d Chemical Battalion from 2002 through 2004 with the rank of Lieutenant Colonel, he integrated his units’ training with civilian agencies, such as [[fire department]]s, [[police station]]s, [[hospital]]s, and [[Non-governmental|non-governmental organizations]] (i.e. [[American Red Cross]] to improve the [[Defense Support of Civil authorities|Defense Support of Civil Authorities]] capabilities for large-scale chemical defense missions. As a result, he was the first commander selected to provide operational command and control over nearly 400 [[CBRN|Chemical, Biological, Radiological, Nuclear and high- yield Explosives]] (CBRNE) defense soldiers in [[Operation Red Dragon (civil defense exercise)|Operation Red Dragon]] in 2004.{{cite web | author= Schuette, Rob | title = Red Dragon tests disaster response | journal= Triad | location= Fort McCoy, WI | date= 8 September 2006 | url = http://www.mccoy.army.mil/vtriad_online/09082006/Red_Dragon_Exercise_09-08-06.htm | quote= Red Dragon began as a small exercise at Fort McCoy in 2004 with 400 Soldiers, who were mostly with chemical organizations ... The exercise grew to 800 Soldiers last year helping to respond to a chemical incident scenario that occurred on the installation. About 1,100 Soldiers from medical, military police, chaplain, and chemical units were included in the exercise this year.| accessdate = 26 July 2015}}{{refn|group=lower-alpha|As a result of the 1995 [[Tokyo subway sarin attack|sarin gas attack on a Tokyo subway]] and the growing concern about a terrorist chemical attack, the [[U.S. Congress]] passed laws to implement a program to train civilian agencies on responding to incidents involving chemical agents.{{cite journal | author= Haraburda, Scott S. | title = U.S. Army Reserve Support for Domestic Response to a Chemical Incident | journal = [[Army Chemical Review]] | pages = 46–50 | date = 2007 | url = http://www.wood.army.mil/chmdsd/images/pdfs/Jan-June_2007/Haraburda-Final.pdf | quote= Colonel Haraburda is a USAR officer and the Commander of the 464th Chemical Brigade. He previously commanded the 472d Chemical Battalion and participated in the first Red Dragon exercise.| accessdate = 23 June 2015 }}}} While commander of the [[464th Chemical Brigade (United States)|464th Chemical Brigade]] from 2006 to 2007, Colonel Haraburda provided command and control over the same exercise in 2006, this time commanding over 1,100 chemical, military police, and medical soldiers.{{refn|group=lower-alpha|Colonel Haraburda laid the groundwork for future training efforts with non-military organizations as part of the [[Defense Support of Civil authorities|Defense Support of Civil Authorities]] for large-scale chemical defense missions, which grew to over 3,000 soldiers with ten civilian hospitals in 2009 and to include foreign contributions with Canadian soldiers in 2014.{{cite journal | author= Vail, Michael S. | title = Exercise Red Dragon 2009 and the CCMRF | journal = Army Chemical Review | pages = 42–43 | date = 2009 | url = http://www.wood.army.mil/chmdsd/images/pdfs/Summer%2009/Red-Dragon-2009-Summer2009.pdf | quote= About 3,000 Soldiers are expected to participate in Red Dragon 2009 at Fort McCoy, Wisconsin, 13–27 June. ... This year’s exercise will involve interactions with first responders, including ten civilian hospitals, from four metropolitan areas in Wisconsin-Milwaukee, Madison, Lacrosse, and Fort McCoy. | accessdate = 23 June 2015 }}{{cite web | author= Hoffart, Matthew | title = Exercise Red Dragon 2014 | website= Lord Strathcona's Horse (Royal Canadians) | date=2014 | quote= The purpose of this visit for the Canadian contingent was to bring back new ideas and help reinvigorate Canadian CBRN doctrine for the 21st century.| accessdate = 26 July 2015}}{{Cite news | author= Baba, Andrew | title= Red Dragon exercise – CBRN training involving Canadian and U.S. Army personnel coming to a close | url= http://ottawacitizen.com/news/national/defence-watch/red-dragon-exercise-cbrn-training-involving-canadian-and-u-s-army-personnel-coming-to-a-close | newspaper= Ottawa Citizen | location= Ottawa, Ontario | date= 20 August 2014 | accessdate= 26 July 2015}}}} Another major contribution he provided to CBRNE soldiers was his recommendations on ways to improve their leadership capabilities, using ideas he derived from his various military leadership assignments and theories learned as a graduate of the [[United States Army War College|Army War College]] and the [[United States Army Command and General Staff College|Army Command and General Staff College]], military colleges that prepare officers for senior leadership assignments and responsibilities.{{refn|group=lower-alpha|Colonel Haraburda’s leadership recommendations were specifically in the areas of: accomplishing tasks, using data, leading people, communicating information, solving problems, and making decisions: Task (Cannot have all three: cheaper, better, and faster; Accomplishing the task more important than the tools; Plan and sacrifice now for the sake of the future; and Implement plans); Data (Use metrics needed to make decisions; Understand the source of the data; Avoid meaningless goals; and Challenge your assumptions); Personnel (Tasks begins and ends with people; Reward good performers and remove bad performers; Train your successor; and You cannot please everyone); Communication (Consensus decision usually results in a weak decision; ensure meetings are short, infrequent, and value-added; Communicate mission results—good and bad; and Communicate good statements); Problem Solving (Today’s problems came from yesterday’s solutions; The cure may be worse than the disease; Dominate technology and do not let it dominate you; and, Solve problems and not symptoms); and Decision Making (Doing the right thing is better than doing things right; ‘Better’ is the enemy of ‘good enough’; Resources mean nothing if they are not used; and If it “ain’t broke,” strive to maintain or improve it).{{cite journal | author= Haraburda Scott S. | title = CBRNE Leadership Rules | journal = Army Chemical Review | pages = 4–7 | date = Winter 2007 | url = http://www.wood.army.mil/chmdsd/images/pdfs/2007%20Winter/Haraburda.pdf | quote= Management and leadership skills are key to success, whether developing and running a large-scale training exercise; decontaminating a chemical, biological, radiological, nuclear, and high-explosive (CBRNE) contaminated area; installing an innovative measurement system in a hazardous-chemical manufacturing company; installing new production equipment for a large international foreign company; or planning a family vacation.| accessdate =10 June 2015 }} }} ===Engineering=== {| style="border-spacing: 2px; border: 3px solid black; background: #FFFFFF;" align=right | colspan="2" style="text-align: center; background: #F5F5DC;"|'''Haraburda Designs''' |- | [[File:MET Sketch 1.jpg|125px]] | [[File:MET Sketch 2.jpg|75px]] |- | colspan="2" align="center" style="border-bottom: 3px solid grey;" | ''[[Ion thrusters#Electromagnetic thrusters|Microwave Electrothermal Thruster]]'' |- | colspan="2" align="center" |[[File:HCHE.jpg|200px]] |- | colspan="2" align="center" | ''[[Heat exchanger#Helical-coil heat exchangers|Helical-Coil Heat Exchanger]]'' |} The [[National Society of Professional Engineers]] named Dr. Scott S. Haraburda a Fellow in 2013 in recognition for long-term service with the Society, as well as to the engineering profession and the community (an honor given to less than 1% of its members).{{cite web | title =Complete List of NSPE Fellows | publisher = National Society of Professional Engineers | url = http://www.nspe.org/membership/about-nspe/complete-list-nspe-fellows | accessdate = 10 June 2015 }}{{cite web |author=Peske, Thomas | title = Crane Army Employee Receives Engineering Society Honor | publisher = United States Army | url = http://www.army.mil/article/106855/ | date= 3 July 2013| accessdate = 10 June 2015 }} And from 2014 until 2015, he served as the president of the Indiana Society of Professional Engineers (ISPE).{{cite web |author=staff |url= http://www.spencereveningworld.com/news/2014-05-27/Front_Page/Haraburda_Named_69th_President_Of_Society_Of_Profe.html | title= Haraburda Named 69th President Of Society Of Professional Engineering | newspaper= Spencer Evening World | date=27 May 2014| volume=87 | issue=231 | page=1 |accessdate=10 June 2015}} While president of ISPE, he publicly led an effort to oppose a state governmental panel recommendation in 2015 to eliminate licensing of engineers in the [[Indiana|State of Indiana]], causing Governor [[Mike Pence]] to soon issue a statement opposing the recommendation as well.{{refn|group=lower-alpha|Dr. Haraburda's actions quickly drew national attention.{{Cite news | author= Kelly, Niki | title= Deregulation of engineers draws fire: Panel supports dropping licenses for 11 jobs | url= http://www.journalgazette.net/news/local/indiana/Deregulation-of-engineers-draws-fire-7899670 | newspaper= The Journal Gazette | location= Fort Wayne, IN | date= 25 July 2015 | accessdate= 31 July 2015}}{{Cite news | title= Indiana panel recommends state stop licensing engineers | url= http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2015/jul/25/indiana-panel-recommends-state-stop-licensing-engi/ | newspaper= The Washington Times | location= Washington, DC | date= 25 July 2015 | accessdate= 31 July 2015 | quote= Scott S. Haraburda, president of the Indiana Society of Professional Engineers, is concerned about the panel’s suggestion that the state stop licensing engineers. He said that a century ago ‘anyone could work as an engineer without proof of competency’ but every U.S. state currently regulates the practice of engineering to ensure public safety. ‘If the recommendations are implemented, Indiana will be the only state that fails to license and regulate its engineers, a dangerous risk that Hoosiers cannot afford to take’}}{{Cite web | title= Indiana panel recommends state stop licensing engineers | url= http://www.sfchronicle.com/news/article/Indiana-panel-recommends-state-stop-licensing-6405371.php | newspaper= San Francisco Chronicles | location= San Francisco, CA | date= 25 July 2015 | quote= Scott S. Haraburda says if the committee's recommendations are implemented it would pose 'a dangerous risk that Hoosiers cannot afford to take. | accessdate= 31 July 2015}}{{cite episode | title= Indiana panel recommends state stop licensing engineers | url = http://www.fox28.com/story/29631735/indiana-panel-recommends-state-stop-licensing-engineers | network = [[WSJV|Fox 28]] | station = WSJV-TV | series= News| location = Elkhart, IN | airdate = 1 August 2015}}{{cite web |author=staff |url= http://www.spencereveningworld.com/news/2015-07-31/Front_Page/Jobs_Committee_Supports_No_State_Licenses_For_11_C.html | title= Jobs Committee Supports No State Licenses For 11 Careers | newspaper= Spencer Evening World | date=31 July 2015| volume=89 | issue=24 | pages=1 | quote= Spencer resident U.S. Army Colonel (ret.) Dr. Scott S. Haraburda has been quoted in recent media coverage from New York to California following preliminary findings by the Indiana Jobs Creation Committee. ... Haraburda is concerned about the lack of licensing for engineers, especially. |accessdate= 31 July 2015}}{{Cite news | author= Kelly, Niki | title= Pence: Don't kill engineer licensing: Calls it a mistake to adopt panel's recommendation | url= http://www.journalgazette.net/news/local/indiana/Pence--Don-t-kill-engineer-licensing-7994773 | newspaper= The Journal Gazette | location= Fort Wayne, IN | date= 31 July 2015 | quote= 'The governor believes it is a mistake not to license engineers and will make sure the recommendation to do so does not stand,' said Kara Brooks, spokeswoman for Pence. | accessdate= 31 July 2015}}}} As an inventor, he holds two [[United States patent law|United States patents]] and seven patent publications. One of Dr. Haraburda's patents involved a measurement system to be used in the [[plastics industry]], which he used in a project identified by Chemical Processing magazine with its '''''Project of the Year''''' award in 1998 as one of the best projects in the [[chemical industry]].{{Citation | inventor-last = Tjahjadi | inventor-first = Mahari | inventor2-last = Janssen | inventor2-first = Joseph | inventor3-last = Fischer | inventor3-first = George | inventor4-last = Lin | inventor4-first = Ye-Gang | inventor5-last = Tadros | inventor5-first = Safrat | inventor6-last = Georgieva | inventor6-first = Galina | inventor7-last = Haraburda | inventor7-first = Scott | issue-date = 2002 | title = Scaleless On-Line Rheometer Device | country-code = US | patent-number = 6405579 }}{{cite journal | title = ''Chemical Processing'' magazine's 1998 Project of the Year Awards: Three companies won accolades, but everyone could benefit | journal = [http://www.chemicalprocessing.com/ Chemical Processing] | volume = 61 | issue =11 | pages = 60–62 | date = 1998 | quote= Online reheometer checks quality: Processes certified correct 99.999+% of the time, winning a CP award for project team. ... The project team used the GE 'Design for Six-Sigma Process' to develop, design and implement the project, according to Scott S. Haraburda, the manufacturing project leader.}}{{refn|group=lower-alpha|The other patent and patent publications involved unique [[information technology]] systems, specifically [[Enterprise Resource Planning]] (ERP) systems within a manufacturing environment.{{Citation | inventor-last = Haraburda | inventor-first = Scott | inventor2-last = Masterson | inventor2-first = Rex | inventor3-last = Clark | inventor3-first = Angelika | inventor4-last = Davis | inventor4-first = Michael | inventor5-last = Klein | inventor5-first = Timothy | inventor6-last = McCarty | inventor6-first = George | issue-date = 2003 | title = Method and System for Electronic Recycle Inventory Tracking | country-code = US | patent-number = 6516280 }}{{Citation | inventor-last = Haraburda | inventor-first = Scott | inventor2-last = Masterson | inventor2-first = Rex | inventor3-last = Clark | inventor3-first = Angelika | inventor4-last = Davis | inventor4-first = Michael | inventor5-last = Clowers | inventor5-first = Clarence | inventor6-last = Dorris | inventor6-first = Dale| inventor7-last = Craddock | inventor7-first = Ronald | publication-date = 2002 | title = Method and System for Electronic Tracking of Packaging | country-code = US | patent-number = 2002077722 }}{{Citation | inventor-last = Haraburda | inventor-first = Scott | inventor2-last = Masterson | inventor2-first = Rex | inventor3-last = Clark | inventor3-first = Angelika | inventor4-last = Davis | inventor4-first = Michael | inventor5-last = McCarty | inventor5-first = George | publication-date = 2002 | title = Method and System for Using Electronic Raw Material Tracking and Quality Control | country-code = US | patent-number = 2002077718 }}{{Citation | inventor-last = Haraburda | inventor-first = Scott | inventor2-last = Masterson | inventor2-first = Rex | inventor3-last = Clark | inventor3-first = Angelika | inventor4-last = Davis | inventor4-first = Michael | inventor5-last = Dorris | inventor5-first = Dale | inventor6-last = Johnson | inventor6-first = Jennifer | publication-date = 2002 | title = Method and System for Using Electronic Raw Material and Formula Verification | country-code = US | patent-number = 2002077717 }}{{Citation | inventor-last = Haraburda | inventor-first = Scott | inventor2-last = Masterson | inventor2-first = Rex | inventor3-last = Clark | inventor3-first = Angelika | inventor4-last = Davis | inventor4-first = Michael | publication-date = 2002 | title = Method and System for Using Electronic Downloadable Control Plans | country-code = US | patent-number = 2002077715 }}{{Citation | inventor-last = Haraburda | inventor-first = Scott | inventor2-last = Masterson | inventor2-first = Rex | inventor3-last = Clark | inventor3-first = Angelika | inventor4-last = McCormick | inventor4-first = Michael | publication-date = 2001 | title = Method and System for Monitoring Production Data | country-code = WO | patent-number = 0150209 }}{{Citation | inventor-last = Haraburda | inventor-first = Scott | publication-date = 2001 | title = Method and System for Visualizing a Production Schedule | country-code = WO | patent-number = 0141540 }}{{Citation | inventor-last = Haraburda | inventor-first = Scott | publication-date = 2001 | title = Method and System for Screen Saver Based Communications | country-code = WO | patent-number = 0127795 }}}} Furthermore, in 2001, he earned a doctorate in [[chemical engineering]] from [[Michigan State University]].{{cite thesis | type= Ph.D. | author= Haraburda, Scott S. | title= Transport phenomena of flow through helium and nitrogen plasmas in microwave electrothermal thrusters | publisher=Michigan State University | year= 2001 | url= http://search.proquest.com/docview/304703595 | accessdate =10 June 2015 }} Dr. Haraburda made significant contributions into optimizing the engineering designs of [[spacecraft propulsion]] and [[heat exchanger]]s. In the early 1990s, he conducted research on a [[Ion thruster#Electromagnetic thrusters|Microwave Electrothermal Thruster]], to which he developed a simple equilibrium based theory of space-dependent parameters for transport design equations, using helium as the [[monatomic gas]] and nitrogen as the diatomic gas.{{refn|group=lower-alpha|Applying the [[Finite Element Method]] (FEM) within the [[plasma (physics)|plasma]] in a [[Batch reactor|Batch Reactor]] model of the TM011 and TM012 [[electromagnetism|electromagnetic]] resonance modes of a [[microwave cavity]], he predicted the residence time of the reaction to equilibrium. With his data, he conducted many simulations on NASA's Two-Dimensional Kinetic (TDK) computer program to determine the effects on engine performance from pressure and energy changes along with propellant contamination. He determined that one should use a minimum power of 1 kWatt to obtain [[specific impulse]]s greater than 1,000 lbf*sec/lb.{{cite conference| author= Haraburda Scott S.| title= Developmental Research for Designing a Microwave Electrothermal Thruster| booktitle= 18th Army Science Conference| volume= 2| pages = 15–29 | date= June 1992| location = Orlando, Florida| url = http://www.dtic.mil/cgi-bin/GetTRDoc?AD=ADA259319 | accessdate= 24 July 2015}}{{cite conference| author= Haraburda, Scott S. | author2= Hawley, Martin C.| title= Investigations of Microwave Plasmas (Applications in Electrothermal Thruster Systems) | booktitle = 25th Joint Propulsion Conference | publisher= AIAA/ASME/SAE/ASEE | date= July 1989| location= Monterey, California| url = http://arc.aiaa.org/doi/abs/10.2514/6.1989-2378| doi=10.2514/3.62304 | accessdate= 24 July 2015}}{{cite conference| author= Haraburda, Scott S. | author2= Hawley, Martin C.| title = Diagnostic Evaluations of Microwave Generated Helium and Nitrogen Plasma Mixtures | booktitle= 21st International Electric Propulsion Conference | publisher= AIAA/DGLR/JSASS | date = July 1990| location = Orlando, Florida| url= http://arc.aiaa.org/doi/abs/10.2514/6.1990-2634| accessdate = 24 July 2015}}{{cite conference| author= Haraburda, Scott S. | author2= Hawley, Martin C.| author3= Dinkel, Duane W. | title = Diagnostic Evaluations of Microwave Generated Helium and Nitrogen Plasma Mixtures | booktitle = 21nd International Electric Propulsion Conference | publisher= AIDAA/AIAA/DGLR/JSASS | date = October 1991| location = Viareggio, Italy}}{{cite conference| author= Haraburda, Scott S. | author2= Hawley, Martin C.| title = Theoretical Nozzle Performance of a Microwave Electrothermal Thruster Using Experimental Data | booktitle = 28th Joint Propulsion Conference | publisher= AIAA/SAE/ASME/ASEE | date = July 1992| location = Nashville, Tennessee| url = http://arc.aiaa.org/doi/abs/10.2514/6.1992-3110 | accessdate = 24 July 2015}}{{cite conference| author= Haraburda, Scott S. | author2= Hawley, Martin C.| author3= Asmussen, Jes | title = Review of Experimental and Theoretical Research on the Microwave Electrothermal Thruster | booktitle = 43rd Congress (World Space Congress) | publisher= International Astronautical Federation | date = September 1992| location = Washington, DC}}{{citation | author= Nickerson, G.R. | author2= Dang, L.D. | author3= Coats, D.E. | title= Engineering and programming manual: Two-dimensional kinetic reference computer program (TDK) | publisher= NASA | url= http://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/19860007470.pdf | accessdate= 24 July 2015}}{{cite thesis | type= Ph.D. | last = Haraburda | first = Scott S. | title= Transport phenomena of flow through helium and nitrogen plasmas in microwave electrothermal thrusters | publisher=Michigan State University | year = 2001 | url = http://search.proquest.com/docview/304703595 | accessdate =23 July 2015 }} He also determined that fouling of the walls in the discharge chamber significantly reduces the amount of energy transferred to the propellant, thus reducing the rocket efficiencies.}} In the mid-1990s, Dr. Haraburda also designed [[Heat exchanger#Helical-coil heat exchangers|Helical-coil heat exchangers]] for fluids with components in multiple phases (solids, liquids, and gases). {{refn|group=lower-alpha|Normal heat exchangers tend to create mechanical problems during operations, such as plugging of small-diameter tubes.{{cite journal | author= Haraburda, Scott S. | title= Three-Phase Flow? Consider Helical-Coil Heat Exchanger | url= http://www.chemengonline.com/articles.php?file=1985-1999/Vol102/chevol102_num7_68.html | journal = Chemical Engineering | pages = 149–151 |volume= 102 |issue= 7 | date= July 1995 | accessdate= 14 July 2015 }} Cleaning of helical coils for these multiple-phase fluids can prove to be more difficult than its shell and tube counterpart; however the helical coil unit would require cleaning less often. There are several simple methods for designing HCHE for all types of manufacturing industries, such as using the Ramachandra K. Patil (et al.) method from [[India]] and the Haraburda method from the [[United States]].{{cite journal | author1 = Patil, Ramachandra K. | author2= Shende, B.W. | author3= Ghosh, Prasanfa K. | title = Designing a helical-coil heat exchanger | url= http://www.researchgate.net/publictopics.PublicPostFileLoader.html?id=54daea37d5a3f295028b45be&key=cd7c7059-0d79-41f2-9d51-56d00af44bad | journal = Chemical Engineering | pages = 85–88 |volume= 92 |issue= 24 | date = 13 December 1982 | accessdate= 14 July 2015 }} However, these are based upon assumptions of estimating inside heat transfer coefficient, predicting flow around the outside of the coil, and upon constant heat flux.{{cite thesis | type= Ph.D. | author= Rennie, Timothy J. | title= Numerical And Experimental Studies Of A Doublepipe Helical Heat Exchanger | publisher= McGill University | location= Montreal | year = 2004 | pages= 3-4 | url = http://webpages.mcgill.ca/staff/deptshare/FAES/066-Bioresource/Theses/theses/308TimothyJohnRennie2004/308TimothyJohnRennie2004.pdf | accessdate=14 July 2015 }} Yet, recent experimental data revealed that the empirical correlations are quite in agreement for designing circular and square pattern HCHEs.{{cite journal | author1= Korane, Ashok B. | author2= Purandare, P.S. | author3= Mali, K.V. | title = Heat Transfer Analysis Of Helical Coil Heat Exchanger With Circular And Square Coiled Pattern | url= http://www.ijesr.org/admin/upload_journal/journal_ashok%20korane%20%203%20jun.pdf | journal = International Journal of Engineering & Science Research | pages = 413–423 |volume= 2 |issue= 6 | date = June 2012| accessdate= 14 July 2015 }} During studies published in 2015, several researchers found that the boundary conditions of the outer wall of exchangers were essentially constant heat flux conditions in power plant boilers, condensers and evaporators; while convective heat transfer conditions were more appropriate in food, automobile and process industries.{{cite journal | author = Kuvadiya, Manish N. | author2= Deshmukh, Gopal K. | author3= Patel, Rankit A. | author4= Bhoi, Ramesh H. | title = Parametric Analysis of Tube in Tube Helical Coil Heat Exchanger at Constant Wall Temperature| journal = International Journal of Engineering Research & Technology | pages = 279–285 | |volume= 1 |issue= 10 | date = April 2015 | url = http://www.ijste.org/articles/IJSTEV1I10146.pdf| accessdate = 14 July 2015 }}}} ==Bibliography== * ''Christian Controversies: Seeking the Truth'' ISBN 978-0988607200, Meaningful Publications, 2013. * ''Premonitions of the Palladion Project'' ISBN 978-1435711150, LuLu Publishing, 2008. ==Notes== {{reflist|group=lower-alpha}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == * [http://www.indspe.org/ Indiana Society of Professional Engineers] * [http://www.nspe.org/membership/about-nspe/complete-list-nspe-fellows List of National Society of Professional Engineers Fellows] * [https://www.cmich.edu/colleges/chsbs/MilitaryScience/Alumni/MSLAlumniHallofFame/Pages/default.aspx#ScottHaraburda Central Michigan University ROTC Hall of Fame] * [https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=VrR6UZsAAAAJ Google Scholar citations for Scott Haraburda] * [https://www.chemicalprocessing.com/ Chemical Processing magazine] {{commons category-inline|Scott S. Haraburda}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Haraburda, Scott}} [[Category:United States Army officers]] [[Category:Recipients of the Legion of Merit]] [[Category:Military personnel from Michigan]] [[Category:United States Army War College alumni]] [[Category:Michigan State University alumni]] [[Category:Central Michigan University alumni]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American colonels]] [[Category:Military personnel from Indiana]] [[Category:United States Army Command and General Staff College alumni]] [[Category:United States Military Academy faculty]] [[Category:1963 births]] [[Category:United States Army Science Board people]]
